Yes, that is true. The Industrial Revolution had significant negative impacts on the working class. While the increased productivity generated greater wealth for factory owners and entrepreneurs, it often resulted in harsh working conditions and low wages for the working class.

The new factories that emerged during the Industrial Revolution were often dirty, unsafe, and poorly ventilated, and workers were required to work long hours in difficult conditions. In addition, workers, including children, were paid very low wages for their labor, and they had few legal protections or rights.

As workers moved from the countryside to the new industrialized cities to seek work, slums and tenements were created, and workers lived in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions. Diseases such as cholera and typhus spread rapidly, and life expectancy was significantly lower for the working class than for the wealthy.

Furthermore, workers had little bargaining power, and many faced periodic bouts of unemployment as factory owners responded to changes in demand. Many workers were also forced to accept inhumane conditions because they had no other choice.

The Industrial Revolution ultimately led to the growth of organized labor movements and the development of new laws and regulations to protect workers. But it also highlights the tension between economic growth and social equity as industrialization created wealth and opportunity for some while leaving others struggling to survive in difficult conditions.
